ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Cholesteatoma (Left Ear)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: The presence of a 'whitish mass' behind the tympanic membrane, combined with a history of frequent ear infections and significant conductive hearing loss, is highly suggestive of a congenital or acquired cholesteatoma.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Chronic Otitis Media with Effusion (Left Ear)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of recent infection following a flight and Type B tympanogram are consistent with effusion, though the specific description of a 'mass' makes this less likely than cholesteatoma.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Eustachian Tube Dysfunction (Right Ear)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Retracted tympanic membrane and Type C tympanogram with negative pressure indicate eustachian tube dysfunction on the right side.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Visual inspection revealed a retracted right TM and a whitish mass behind the left TM.
Assessed middle ear function, showing Type C (right) and Type B (left) patterns.
Established normal hearing in the right ear and moderate conductive loss in the left ear.
Likely to be ordered by ENT to determine the extent of the mass/cholesteatoma.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The patient presents with a unilateral (left) moderate conductive hearing loss and a 'whitish mass' in the middle ear, strongly suggesting cholesteatoma. The right ear shows evidence of negative pressure (Eustachian tube dysfunction) but normal hearing sensitivity.

tests.name: Otoscopy
tests.result_summary: Right: Retracted TM. Left: Whitish mass behind TM.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Right: Type C (-250 daPa). Left: Type B (flat).

tests.name: Wideband Reflectance
tests.result_summary: Right: Dip at 1.5 kHz. Left: Abnormally high reflectance (80-90%).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right: Normal hearing (0-10 dB HL). Left: Moderate rising conductive loss with 50-55 dB air-bone gaps in low frequencies.

proposed_items: Referral to Otolaryngologist (ENT) for evaluation of left middle ear mass.
Potential surgical intervention (e.g., tympanomastoidectomy) if cholesteatoma is confirmed.
Monitoring of right ear for progression of Eustachian tube dysfunction.
counseling_actions: Explain the difference between the conductive loss in the left ear and normal hearing in the right.
Discuss the significance of the 'whitish mass' and the necessity of medical follow-up to prevent complications.
Review the implications of negative pressure in the right ear.
Advise the patient to report any changes in hearing, drainage, or dizziness immediately.

red_flags_present: Visible mass behind the tympanic membrane

escalation.rationale_short: The presence of a middle ear mass (suspected cholesteatoma) requires specialist evaluation to prevent bone erosion and other complications.

follow_up_plan.objective: Re-evaluate hearing thresholds to assess the outcome of medical or surgical management.

expected_outcome: Diagnosis confirmation via imaging or surgery.
Potential restoration of hearing thresholds following surgical management.
Prevention of long-term complications associated with cholesteatoma.
